useful. Also, you may need to divide ε\varepsilonε as ε=ε3+ε3+ε3\varepsilon = \frac{\varepsilon}{3} + \frac{\varepsilon}{3} + \frac{\varepsilon}{3}ε=3ε​+3ε​+3ε​. Theorem (3.3.1)

Suppose (f(n))n=1∞\p{f^{\p{n}}}_{n=1}^\infty(f(n))n=1∞​ is a sequence of functions from one metric space (X,dX)\p{X, d_X}(X,dX​) to another (Y,dY)\p{Y, d_Y}(Y,dY​), and suppose that this sequence converges uniformly to another function f ⁣:X→Y\func{f}{X}{Y}f:X→Y. Fix n0=Nn_0 = Nn0​=N and let δ=δn0\delta = \delta_{n_0}δ=δn0​​. If dX(x,x0)<δd_X\p{x, x_0} < \deltadX​(x,x0​)<δ, then

For the first and third terms, we have n0≥Nn_0 \geq Nn0​≥N, so (∗*∗) is applicable. Lastly, for the second term, we assumed dX(x,x0)<δn0d_X\p{x, x_0} < \delta_{n_0}dX​(x,x0​)<δn0​​, so (†\dagger†) is applicable.
